greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T, read by rows, where row n+1 of T = row n of T^(2n-1) with appended '1' for n>=0 with T(0,0)=1.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..140, flattened
formula: T(n+1,1) is divisible by 2n-1 for n>=1.
example: Triangle begins:
GENERATE T FROM ODD MATRIX POWERS OF T.
Matrix cube, T^3, begins:
where row 3 of T = row 2 of T^3 with appended '1'.
Matrix fifth power, T^5, begins:
where row 4 of T = row 3 of T^5 with appended '1'.
Matrix seventh power, T^7, begins:
where row 5 of T = row 4 of T^7 with appended '1'.
ALTERNATE GENERATING METHOD.
Row 4: start with a '1' followed by 4 zeros;
take partial sums and append 2 zeros; then
take partial sums thrice more:
the final nonzero terms form row 4: [80, 25, 5, 1, 1].
Row 5: start with a '1' followed by 6 zeros;
take partial sums and append 4 zeros;
take partial sums and append 2 zeros; then
take partial sums thrice more:
the final nonzero terms form row 5: [1666, 378, 56, 7, 1, 1].
Continuing in this way produces all the rows of this triangle.
maple: seq(seq(T(n,k), k=0..n), n=0..10);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Apr 13 2020
mathematica: b[n_] := b[n] = MatrixPower[Table[T[i-1, j-1], {i, n}, {j, n}], 2n-3];
Table[T[n, k], {n, 0, 10}, {k, 0, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 27 2020, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: (PARI) {T(n, k)=local(A=vector(n+1), p); A[1]=1; for(j=1, n-k-1, p=(n-1)*(n-2)-(n-j-1)*(n-j-2); A=Vec((Polrev(A)+x*O(x^p))/(1-x))); A=Vec((Polrev(A)+x*O(x^p))/(1-x)); A[p+1]}
results.author: _Paul D. Hanna_, Aug 24 2007
